payload.text: Did you know? Santa's workshop at the North Pole employs thousands of elves who work year-round to prepare gifts for children around the world!
Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer was created in 1939 by Robert L. May for a Montgomery Ward marketing campaign. His glowing red nose helps guide Santa's sleigh through foggy weather!
The tradition of decorating Christmas trees began in Germany in the 16th century. It was brought to America by German immigrants in the 1800s.

payload.text: Legend has it that in 1670, a choirmaster in Germany gave candy canes to children to keep them quiet during long church services. The shape was meant to remind them of shepherds who visited baby Jesus.

payload.text: In Japan, it's traditional to eat KFC on Christmas Eve! This started from a successful marketing campaign in 1974 and has become a beloved tradition.

payload.text: 'Jingle Bells' was originally written for Thanksgiving! James Lord Pierpont composed it in 1857 under the title 'One Horse Open Sleigh' and it was only later associated with Christmas.

payload.text: The first commercial Christmas card was created in London in 1843 by Sir Henry Cole. He commissioned artist John Callcott Horsley to design the card, which featured a family raising a toast.

payload.text: The Nutcracker ballet, based on E.T.A. Hoffmann's story, premiered in 1892 in St. Petersburg, Russia. Today, it's one of the most performed ballets during the Christmas season worldwide!
Every year, the United States Postal Service receives hundreds of thousands of letters addressed to Santa Claus at the North Pole. The postal code for Santa's Workshop is H0H 0H0 in Canada!

payload.text: To visit every child on Christmas Eve, Santa's sleigh would need to travel at about 650 miles per second! That's roughly 3,000 times the speed of sound. Good thing it's magic!

payload.text: If you received all the gifts from 'The Twelve Days of Christmas,' you'd have 364 presents! That includes 12 partridges, 22 turtle doves, 30 French hens, and much more.

payload.text: Santa's nine reindeer are: Dasher, Dancer, Prancer, Vixen, Comet, Cupid, Donner, Blitzen, and Rudolph. Their names were first published in the 1823 poem 'A Visit from St. Nicholas' (except Rudolph, who came later in 1939).
